temperatureScales.name: Kelvin
temperatureScales.description: The Kelvin scale is a thermodynamic (absolute) temperature scale where absolute zero, the lowest possible temperature, is defined as 0 K.
keyPoints: Does not use degrees, only kelvins (K)
The triple point of water is 273.16 K
Increments of 1 K equal increments of 1Â°C

temperatureScales.name: Degree Celsius
temperatureScales.description: The Celsius scale, formerly known as the centigrade scale, is based on the freezing point (0Â°C) and boiling point (100Â°C) of water at 1 atmosphere of pressure.
keyPoints: Used in most of the world

temperatureScales.name: Degree Fahrenheit
temperatureScales.description: Developed by Daniel Fahrenheit, this scale uses as reference a mixture of ice, water, and ammonium salt (0Â°F) and human body temperature (originally 96Â°F, now 98.6Â°F).
keyPoints: 0Â°F = freezing point of a saline mixture

temperatureScales.name: Rankine
temperatureScales.description: The Rankine scale is an absolute temperature scale based on the Fahrenheit scale. It is the Fahrenheit equivalent of the Kelvin scale.

temperatureScales.name: Degree Newton
temperatureScales.description: Developed by Isaac Newton for his thermal experiments. Newton was a pioneer in the systematic study of temperature.

temperatureScales.name: Degree Delisle
temperatureScales.description: An inverse scale created by French astronomer Joseph-Nicolas Delisle. It is unique because values decrease as temperature increases.

curiosities.text: The original Celsius scale was inverted: 0Â° for boiling and 100Â° for freezing.
Fahrenheit based his scale on three points: saline mixture (0Â°F), ice-water (32Â°F), and body temperature (96Â°F).
Kelvin is the only scale that does not use the term 'degrees', only 'kelvins'.
Only three countries use Fahrenheit as their main scale: the U.S., Bahamas, and Cayman Islands.
Delisle is the only scale where temperature decreases as it gets hotter.

introText.title: What is a temperature scale?
introText.description: A temperature scale is a system used to measure temperature quantitatively. It assigns numbers to different levels of heat or cold.
points: Fixed points: Reference temperatures such as water freezing/boiling
Increments: How the interval between fixed points is divided
Zero: The point where the scale begins (relative or absolute)

finalNote.title: Why so many scales?
finalNote.text: Each scale was developed in different historical and scientific contexts. Some aimed for greater precision, others for ease of use, and others were based on available materials (such as mercury vs alcohol). Today, Celsius and Kelvin dominate science, while Fahrenheit persists by tradition in some countries.
